Free thinking is thinking that allows itself to question any or all aspect of human knowledge. Rational thinking takes accepted knowledge as a base and progresses from there through logical analyis to attain new knowledge. 
 
 I would say that religious thinking can be rational since it can use logical analyis of accepted religious and secular knowledge to reach further understanding. However, it is not entirely free since some basic assumptions (such as the very existence of God or a supernatural) are not fully questioned. The trouble, of course, with rational thinking that is not free is that, if the original accepted knowledge is not correct, then any new knowledge one gains from its analysis can also easily be false. So, like a carefully constructed house of cards, it can fall apart due to the poor base. 
 
 That restrained rational thinking was the only route for scholars for many centuries. It is only once it was freed from the cage of authority (either religious or secular - ex. in assuming that Aristotle had to be right) through the Enlightment that the attainment of knowledge really took off - mainly through Science.
 
 To be fair, the progress of Science is also occasionally impeded by constrained thinking since Science, after all, is pursued by scientists who can succumb to human limitations - such as the egos of scientists who find it very hard to part with certain pet theories, or the enormous obstacles that a scientist can encounter when trying to refute a popularly accepted theory, even if they can present just as supportable a theory. Nonetheless, most limited thinking in Science is eventually ironed out, allowing scientific knowledge to progress.

If the soul does not contain a sense of personality or mental capability, then that would be very dissappointing and would give much less solace to someone grieving for a loved one - since the person they knew really would be gone forever. Perhaps some "essence of life" survives, but that is not nearly as emotionally sattisfying.
